questions.text: Which of these is a red flag for a fake shopping website?

choices.text: Prices that are unusually low for luxury items

questions.explanation: Unrealistically low prices are often used to lure buyers to fake stores.

questions.text: Before making a purchase on a new website, you should:

choices.text: Verify the site’s URL and look for reviews online
Trust a link shared on social media
Assume the site is safe because it looks professional

questions.explanation: Check the URL and reviews to confirm a site’s legitimacy before paying.

questions.text: A suspicious website may:

choices.text: Lack contact information or a customer service phone number

questions.explanation: Missing contact details or support is a common sign of a fraudulent site.

questions.text: Which URL is likely legitimate?
questions.explanation: Official brand domains (correct spelling, HTTPS) indicate legitimacy.

questions.text: To stay safe when shopping online, you should:

choices.text: Use a friend’s account to buy items
Only enter payment details on verified, HTTPS-secured websites
Click links in unsolicited emails offering discounts
Trust the site if it looks visually appealing

questions.explanation: Only enter payment details on secure, verified checkout pages (HTTPS + trusted gateway).

questions.text: Which of the following is a sign of a fake login page?

choices.text: URL does not match the official website

questions.explanation: A mismatched or misleading URL strongly suggests a phishing page.

questions.text: What should you do if you are unsure about a login page’s authenticity?

choices.text: Go directly to the website by typing the URL manually
Ask a friend to log in for you
Click links from emails to verify

questions.explanation: Typing the known URL prevents landing on spoofed pages linked in emails or ads.

questions.text: A phishing login page may try to:
questions.explanation: Phishing pages are designed to capture credentials for later misuse.

questions.text: Which is a safe login practice?

choices.text: Use the same password for multiple websites
Enable two-factor authentication (2FA) on your accounts
Enter your password only when prompted via email links
Keep your password in a shared document

questions.explanation: 2FA adds an extra layer of protection even if a password is compromised.

questions.text: If you suspect a fake login page, you should:

choices.text: Reply to the website owner for confirmation
Close the page and report it if possible
Ignore it but keep your credentials ready

questions.explanation: Close the page and report phishing to help block the site and protect others.

questions.text: Which pop-up is most likely a phishing attempt?

choices.text: “Your computer is infected! Click here to fix immediately”

questions.explanation: Scare pop-ups urging immediate action often try to trick you into installing malware.

questions.text: What is the safest action when encountering a suspicious pop-up?

choices.text: Click it to see what happens
Close it using the browser’s X button or Task Manager
Enter your login info to continue

questions.explanation: Closing the pop-up without interacting avoids accidental downloads or redirects.

questions.text: A red flag in pop-ups includes:

choices.text: Urgent messages asking for personal information

questions.explanation: Urgent requests for personal data through pop-ups are suspicious and unsafe.

questions.text: Which method helps prevent phishing pop-ups?

choices.text: Keep your browser and antivirus updated
Reply to the pop-up to ask if it’s real

questions.explanation: Keeping software updated reduces vulnerabilities that pop-ups may exploit.

questions.text: Legitimate websites usually:

choices.text: Use aggressive pop-ups for urgent warnings
Do not ask for passwords or payment info in pop-ups
Redirect you to unknown sites randomly

questions.explanation: Real sites avoid requesting sensitive info through intrusive pop-ups.

questions.text: Which of these indicates a potentially unsafe payment process?

choices.text: Requesting payment via wire transfer to unknown accounts

questions.explanation: Requesting wire transfers to unknown accounts is a common scam payment method.

questions.text: Which is safest for online payment?
questions.explanation: Trusted payment gateways protect your card data and add transaction security.

questions.text: Red flags in payment forms include:

choices.text: Requests for unnecessary personal information (like PINs or social security numbers)

questions.explanation: Legitimate forms won’t ask for sensitive details that are unnecessary for payment.

questions.text: When a website offers extreme discounts but asks for upfront payment via unusual methods, you should:

choices.text: Take the deal before it expires
Verify the site and consider it a potential scam
Trust the deal if the site looks professional

questions.explanation: Unusual payment requests combined with extreme discounts are a major red flag.

questions.text: To stay safe while paying online, you should:

choices.text: Always save your card details for convenience
Check URLs, use verified gateways, and avoid unsolicited payment requests
Click links in emails for secure payment
Share your credentials with friends for validation

questions.explanation: Verifying URLs and using trusted gateways helps prevent payment fraud.
